In the present study, TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 catalysts were used to investigate the catalytic performance in methyl palmitate ketonization. The reaction was accelerated by weak Lewis acid, while the oxygen vacancies promoted the palmitone selectivity. The use of various characterization techniques revealed that oxygen vacancies played an important role for trapping the hydrogen atom and inhibited its spillover. This caused the suppression of the Lewis acid transformation to new Bronsted acid. Thus, the cracking of palmitone over the new Bronsted acid was diminished, leading to the decrement of selectivity to undesired products. However, when the hydrogen atom was trapped in the oxygen vacancies, the coke deposition was dominant. This phenomenon arose because hydrogen could not suppress the deep dehydrogenation, resulting in the transformation of aliphatic coke to aromatic coke. The role of oxygen vacancies was determined, and it had the positive effect on the palmitone selectivity, whereas it raised the coke formation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ketonization Long-chain methyl ester Oxygen vacancies Hydrogen trapping Catalyst deactivation Liquid phase 1 Introduction Nowadays, biomass-derived hydrocarbon fuels have gained significant attention as alternative energy sources owing to increasing in the demand for fossil fuels and growing in concerns on climate change [1,2]. Biomass has a significant contribution to the world economy and provides a range of biofuels and chemicals [2,3]. In the plant-based oil-production regions, especially in Southeast Asia, the palm oil has been oversupplied [4]. Therefore, the palm oil conversion to other higher value-added products is of much interest. Green diesel recognized as the fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) is one of the targeted products [5,6]. However, at present energy policies in many countries encourage the utilization of electric vehicles leading to a decrease in the demand of biodiesel suppressed the demand for the FAME. Consequently, the ketonization process can be the solution towards the utilization of the FAME for production of higher value-added chemicals, especially, ketone products which are used for many applications such as ink manufacturing, corrosion inhibition, and dishwashing detergents [1,7,8]. Ketonization of the carboxylic acids on various metal oxides has been investigated on MgO [9,10], Nb2O5 [11], CeO2 [12–16], MnO2 [12,17], TiO2 [13,18–20], Al2O3 [17,21], ZrO2 [12,22], Cr2O3 [23,24], and Fe2O3 [13]. The reaction mechanisms were reported depending on different metal oxide catalysts. Previously, two mechanisms have been proposed on the metal oxides. The first mechanism is the decomposition of surface/bulk carboxylates to form ketones, which undergoes effectively on low-lattice-energy oxides such as alkali and alkaline earth oxides. The second one is the formation of ketene-like intermediates by abstraction of α-H of carboxylic acid over high-lattice-energy oxides such as TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 [1,14,17,25,26]. Generally, these mechanisms lead to the adsorption of a carboxylic acid as a carboxylate on a Lewis acid site [1,27,28]. Another proposed parameter that can be linked to the catalytic performance is surface oxygen vacancies. The oxygen vacancies could be improved by the addition of dopants and prereduction treatments [1,8,29–31]. Generally, the ketonization can convert two carboxylic acid molecules into a ketone, carbon dioxide, and water. Thus, the ketonization can play an important role in biomass conversion processes because it enables the removal of the highly reactive carboxylic groups, while increasing the carbon chain length [1]. The ketonization process can be conducted in a continuous flow reactor at 350–400 °C [8,26,32]. This reaction can be also applied directly to esters, but less interesting since the selectivity to the ketone was lower than the carboxylic acids. Furthermore, shorter ketones and hydrocarbons were obtained as by-products when esters are used as feedstock [8,10,33]. Cracking could occur coupled with the ketonization causing the formation of undesired products such as light hydrocarbons and short-chain alkanes with lower energy densities. Bronsted acid site is well known as the responsible site for cracking, isomerization, and rapid deactivation via coking [34]. In the ketonization process, substrate and ketone product could be cracked. Light alkanes generated by cracking of methyl palmitate during catalytic hydrodeoxygenation or decarboxylation were presented as reported by many researchers [35,36]. In addition, the methylketone and hydrocarbons could be also generated via cracking of ketone major product [33,37]. Maluangnont et al. [38] reported that heavy ketone (mostly C17 ketone) and hydrocarbons (< C14) were generated by the cracking of palmitone. In this work, the ketonization of methyl palmitate to palmitone was studied since methyl palmitate is abundant in palm oil biodiesel [39,40]. Thereby, it is a big challenge to investigate the ketonization of long-chain methyl esters. More research is needed to explore its potential for future industries. The reaction was conducted in the gas phase over heterogeneous catalysts such as TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 at 400 °C under atmosphere pressure. The influences of oxygen vacancies on the catalytic performance and coke formation were elucidated by comparing their changes in surface chemistry during the ketonization. These can be proven by various characterization techniques including in situ DRIFTS of ammonia adsorption (NH3-IR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD), temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO), and ex situ Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Commercial TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 catalysts were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. The catalyst powder was compressed by iron mold (10 N cm−2). Then, it was transformed into thin sheet. After that, the sheet was crushed and sieved in a range of 0.40–0.80 mm. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area (SBET), average mean pore diameter, and pore volume (Vpore) were obtained from nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms collected on a Micromeritics 3Flex 3500 series with Smart VacPrep. The sample was outgassed in N2 for 4 h before performing N2 physisorption at −196 °C. The crystallinities were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. The X-ray diffractometer SIEMENS D5000 was connected to a computer with Diffract AT version 3.3 program for full control of the XRD analyzer. 2-theta degree was varied from 20° to 80°. The in situ DRIFTS of ammonia adsorption (NH3-IR) was used to observe the acidity types, Lewis acid sites (LAS) and Bronsted acid sites (BAS), on the catalysts. The experiment was conducted in a Bruker Vertex-70 FT-IR spectrometer. The sample (160 mg) was loaded into an IR cell. The sample was pretreated under N2 flow at 500 °C for 1 h. Then, the sample was cooled down to 40 °C. Subsequently, a background spectrum was recorded. After that, 15% NH3 in He was introduced for 30 min, followed by the introduction of N2 for 1 h to remove physisorbed ammonia. Then, the FTIR spectrum was recorded again. The peaks of chemisorbed ammonia were obtained by subtracting the background spectrum. Moreover, the relative strength of LAS and BAS was investigated by the thermodesorption of NH3 at 150, 300, and 400 °C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was determined to investigate the oxygen vacancies (OV), sub oxide (OS), and the chemical state of Mn, Ti, Ce, and Zr. The XPS spectra were obtained by AMICUS spectrometer using Mg Kα X-ray radiation and Al Kα X-ray radiation at voltage 15 kV and current of 12 mA. The energy gap was obtained by the ultraviolet–visible spectrophotometry (UV–Vis), in which the absorbance from 200 to 600 nm was obtained by AvaSpec 2048L spectrometer. Light source was provided by the AvaLight-DH-S deuterium halogen source. Coke formation was examined by temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO). The spent catalyst was loaded in a quartz tube with flowing 1%O2 in He and heated until the temperature reached 950 °C (5 °C min−1). The TPO experiment was conducted on a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2750 automated system. CO2 gas was analyzed every 5 min online by a Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatograph with an Rt®-Q-BOND-fused silica plot column. In addition, the coke structures were determined by the ex situ Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy. The hydrogen chemisorption was investigated by temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD). The experiments were conducted on the Micromeritics Chemisorbs 2750 automatic system with a thermal conductivity detector. The sample (100 mg) was pretreated under H2 flow (99.99%, 25 ml min−1) at 400 °C for 1 h. Then, the sample was cooled down to 40 °C under N2 flow (99.999%, 25 ml min−1), followed by the H2 saturation for 30 min. After the saturation, the N2 was introduced into the quartz tube instead of H2. Subsequently, a TPD experiment was performed up to 800 °C (10 °C min−1) and hold at 800 °C for 1 h. 2.3 Catalyst performance testing The ketonization was performed in a fixed-bed tubular reactor (11.45 mm of internal diameter). At the beginning, the catalyst (2.5 g) was physically mixed with silicon carbide (2.0 g) and they were loaded in the reactor. The catalyst was pretreated in N2 flow (100 ml min−1) at 400 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, methyl palmitate in n-dodecane (10% W/V) was introduced into the reactor with a rate of 1.27 ml min−1 using HPLC pump and the N2 gas was still fed as a carrier gas. The reaction was conducted for 2 h time on stream (TOS). In addition, the heating tapes were provided before and after the reactor for being pre-evaporation zone at 50 °C and to keep the liquid nature of the product at 120 °C to prevent the occurrence of wax-like product, leading to blocked line system, respectively. The condensed sample cooled down by ice bath was collected every 30 min and dissolved wax-like by chloroform. After the ketonization testing, the n-dodecane was used to clean the process line for eliminating trace contaminants or remaining substrate in the feed inlet since they could cause wax blocking in the line process. The liquid product was analyzed by off-line gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) using DB-1 capillary column (15 m × 0.53 mm × 0.15 µm). The conversion of methyl palmitate and products selectivity were calculated on a mass basis: PAME conv. % = (PAME)in (internal standard)in − (PAME)out (internal standard)out ( PAME)in (internal standard)in x 100 Palmitone sel. (%) = ( palmitone ) out ( internal standard)out ( PAME ) in (internal standard)in − ( PAME ) out (internal standard)out x 100 Cracking % = ( cracking products ) out (internal standard)out ( PAME ) in (internal standard)in − ( PAME ) out (internal standard)out x 100 where (PAME)in was the methyl palmitate in feed. (PAME)out, (palmitone)out and (cracking products) out were the contents of methyl palmitate, palmitone, and by-products in the effluent gas, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of fresh catalysts The textural properties of the various metal oxide catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption–desorption as reported in Table S1†. The SBET of the catalysts was in the range of 3.9–8.3 m2 g−1. The pore size and the Vpore of the catalysts were in the range of 45.7–57.7 nm and 0.0197–0.1038 cm3 g−1, respectively. Fig. 1 (black line) displays the XRD patterns of the catalysts. The XRD peak position and intensity for TiO2 phase are matched with the JCPDS database. Generally, anatase phase of TiO2 presents diffraction peaks at 2θ of 24.8°, 37.3°, 47.6°, 53.5°, 55.1°, and 62.2° [JCPDS Card No. 21-1272]. The XRD pattern of CeO2 consists of seven reflections at 2θ of 28.57°, 33.00°, 47.60°, 56.39°, 59.13°, 69.51° and 76.69°, corresponding to CeO2 Cubic [JCPDS Card No. 81-0792]. The XRD pattern of MnO2 appeared at 2θ of 28.68°, 37.36°, 41.04°, 42.82°, 56.65°, 59.37° and 72.38°, which can be indexed to β-MnO2 [JCPDS Card No. 24-0735]. The XRD pattern of ZrO2 presents many diffraction peaks at 2θ of 28.2, 31.5, 33.8, 35.1, 38.5, 40.5, 44.5, 45.3, 50.3, 50.9, 53.8, 55.3, 57.0, 57.7 and 60.1 assigned to monoclinic structure of ZrO2 [JCPDS Card No. 37-1484]. The acidity types were investigated using the in situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption at 40 °C as shown in Fig. 2. The bands at 1220–1280 cm−1 and 1600 cm−1 are assigned to NH3 chemisorbed on the LAS, and the bands at 1470 cm−1 and 1680 cm−1 are ascribed to NH4 + species chemisorbed on the BAS [41–43]. The relative strength of LAS and BAS was observed by the NH3 thermodesorption experiments at 150, 300, and 400 °C. It was clear that the bands corresponding to the LAS on CeO2 and TiO2 obviously decreased with the increment of temperature from 150 °C, but those of ZrO2 were decreased after the temperature was reached to 300 °C. At 400 °C, no IR spectra assigned to LAS were observed on CeO2. This means that the LAS on TiO2 and ZrO2 are stronger than those on CeO2 catalysts. Meanwhile, the bands corresponding to the BAS on all catalysts also decreased obviously with elevated temperatures starting from 150 °C. The bands of BAS mostly disappeared for only CeO2 when the temperature reached at 300 °C, indicating the weaker BAS over its surface. Oxygen vacancies were determined by the XPS technique as shown in Fig. 3(a, c, e, and g). Table S2† displays O 1s peaks area in the XPS spectra and the percentage of oxygen vacancy sites. The O 1s spectra consist of three peaks at 529.7–529.8, 530.4–531.4 and 532.6–533.4 eV. Each peak was assigned to lattice oxygen (OL), oxygen vacancies (OV), and sub oxide (OS), respectively [44]. It indicates that the oxygen vacancies (OV) increased in the order of ZrO2 (29.1%) < CeO2 (32.8%) < TiO2 (40.3%) < MnO2 (48.2%). Besides, the XPS spectra profiles are illustrated in Fig. 4(a, c, e, and g). It reveals the changes in elemental chemical state of Ti, Ce, Mn, and Zr. On the Ti species of the TiO2, the Ti4+ 2p3/2 peaks were detected at 458.0 and 464.1 eV. In addition, the Ti3+ 2p1/2 peak, which was classified to the Ti2O3 phase, occurred between the peaks of Ti4+ 2p3/2 at 459.0 eV [44]. The Ce 3d spectrum shows eight peaks, attributing to the Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2. The peaks at 884.1, 885.9, 890.4, and 899.5 eV belong to the Ce 3d5/2, whereas the peaks at 902.5, 904.7, 908.4, and 917.8 eV are assigned to the Ce 3d3/2. The peaks at binding energy values of 884.1, 890.4, 899.5, 904.7, 908.4, and 917.8 eV were assigned to Ce4+. The peaks at 885.9 and 902.5 eV were attributed to the chemical state of Ce3+ [45]. The XPS spectra of Mn 2p exhibited four peaks at 642.3, 643.3, 653.8, and 654.8 eV. These peaks were assigned to the Mn3+ 2p3/2, Mn4+ 2p3/2, Mn3+ 2p1/2, and Mn4+ 2p1/2 species, respectively [46]. Based on the changes in the elemental chemical state of Zr species, there were two chemical states for each of Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2. The binding energies were 182.0, 183.8, 186.0, and 186.3, corresponding to the Zr3+ 3d5/2, Zr4+ 3d5/2, Zr3+ 3d3/2, and Zr4+ 3d3/2, respectively [47]. In this work, the reduction of the chemical state of the metal from 4+ to 3+ was found in all catalysts confirming to the appearance of oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, the UV–Vis spectroscopy result was also provided to confirm the presence of the oxygen vacancies. The oxygen vacancies induced the formation of the interstate leading to a decrease of band gap energy (Eg). The reduction in Eg causes surface characteristic changing from semiconductor–like to a more metallic–like. The oxygen atoms are lost until they formed the oxygen vacancy site [48–51]. Fig. S1† shows the plot of (αhν)2 (cm−1 eV)2 against hν (photo energy, eV), where α, h, and ν represent absorption coefficient, Planck’s constant, and light frequency, respectively. Extrapolating the linear portion of the curve to the energy-axis gives the values of the direct band gap (Eg). The degree of Eg over the fresh catalyst increased in the following order: MnO2 (1.51 eV) < TiO2 (3.06 eV) < CeO2 (3.20 eV) < ZrO2 (4.06 eV). It indicates that the presence of oxygen vacancy increased in the following order: ZrO2 < CeO2 < TiO2 < MnO2, which was consistent with the XPS result. The hydrogen chemisorption was investigated by the H2-TPD experiments and the profiles are presented in Fig. 5. Generally, lower temperature desorption peaks belong to hydrogen desorbed from metal sites, while higher temperature desorption peaks (500–800 °C) are referred to hydrogen spillover species [52,53]. No signal was observed at low temperature region for all catalysts, indicating that there was no hydrogen adsorbed on the metal sites. Apparently, there were large peaks of hydrogen desorbed from the catalysts at high temperature regions, which were assigned to hydrogen spillover species. The amounts of hydrogen spillover on the catalysts were also calculated from the integrated peak areas, which were in the following order: MnO2 (24.0 µmol H2 gcat−1) < TiO2 (39.0 µmol H2 gcat−1) < CeO2 (43.7 µmol H2 gcat−1) < ZrO2 (53.1 µmol H2 gcat−1). 3.2 Catalyst performance In the present study, TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 were used as the catalysts for the ketonization of methyl palmitate. The catalytic performance of these metal oxides was evaluated at 400 °C under atmospheric pressure for 2 h as shown in Fig. 6a. In general, the ketonization of the methyl palmitate produces symmetrical ketone product as described in the equation below. Meanwhile, carbon dioxide and dimethyl ether are also produced as by-products [33]. 2 [CH3(CH2)13CH2COOCH3] → CH3(CH2)14CO(CH2)14CH3 + CO2 + CH3OCH3 It was found that the conversions of methyl palmitate were in the range of 24–40% and slightly decreased with TOS. The conversions of methyl palmitate increased in the following order: TiO2 (24.4%) < ZrO2 (27.5%) < CeO2 (37.2%) < MnO2 (40.2%). The selectivity to palmitone was in the wide range of 28–70% (Fig. 6b). This is because various cracking products were generated. The product distributions after the ketonization of methyl palmitate are summarized in Table 1. Cracking reaction could occur coupled with the ketonization and it causes the formation of undesired products such as light hydrocarbons and short-chain alkanes with lower energy densities. In the ketonization process, substrate and produced ketone could be cracked. Light alkanes generated by cracking of methyl palmitate during catalytic hydrodeoxygenation or decarboxylation were reported by many researchers [35,36]. It was also found that methylketone and hydrocarbons could be formed via cracking of ketone major product [33,37]. Maluangnont et al. [38] reported that heavy ketone (mostly C17 ketone) and hydrocarbons (< C14) were generated via the cracking of palmitone. The result shows that MnO2 exhibited the highest selectivity to palmitone, followed by TiO2, CeO2, and ZrO2. During the catalytic testing, there were the variety of products produced from the cracking of hydrocarbon and palmitone. However, the undesired products were summarized into two groups; one came from methyl palmitate cracking (identified as hydrocarbon cracking) and the other one was derived by palmitone cracking. It seemed that the latter gave higher number of undesired products than the former. Besides, the overall cracking is summarized in the Table 1 as shown in the following order: CeO2 > ZrO2 > TiO2 > MnO2. This led to the highest palmitone selectivity derived from the MnO2 catalyst. A large number of researchers revealed that the acidity including LAS and BAS, directly affected the catalytic activity, selectivity to desired and undesired products, and coke formation. The percentages of weak, medium, and strong LAS and BAS were calculated from the subtraction of peak areas from the in situ DRIFTS of NH3 thermodesorption results as summarized in Table 2. It is noted that IR cannot be emitted owing to its dark brown of MnO2 catalyst, and consequently, there was no spectrum of NH3 adsorption for MnO2. In this work, the peak areas in the temperature range of lower than 150 °C, 150–300 °C, and above 300 °C were assigned to weak, medium, and strong acid sites, respectively. The percentage of LAS over CeO2 mostly inclined to weak LAS while those on ZrO2 and TiO2 were medium and strong LAS, respectively. The total LAS were in the following order: ZrO2 > CeO2 > TiO2. However, the areas of the weak LAS decreased in the following order: CeO2 > ZrO2 > TiO2. For the BAS, most BAS on CeO2 were weak, while those on ZrO2 and TiO2 were medium acid sites. In addition, Table 2 provides a summarized data for the acidity and the oxygen vacancies of TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 catalysts, which were related to the catalytic activity and products selectivity. Surprisingly, ZrO2, which exhibited the highest number of total LAS, did not give the highest conversion of methyl palmitate. Essentially, CeO2 contained fewer total LAS than ZrO2, turned to render the highest methyl palmitate conversion. Therefore, it was evident that the ketonization activity did not depend only on the number of total LAS. Therefore, the surface acidity was further investigated in term of acid strength. The number of weak LAS decreased in the following order: CeO2 > ZrO2 > TiO2, which followed the similar trend to the ketonization activity. It was suggested that weak LAS were the active sites for the ketonization of methyl palmitate as reported by Jahangiri et al. [54,55]. Oxygen vacancies were also proposed to relate with the ketonization activity [1,8,29–31]. Oxygen vacancies could be improved by the addition of dopants and prereduction treatments. Hessam et al. investigated the effect of different calcination temperatures on the oxygen vacancies and LAS. They revealed an increase in the surface oxygen vacancy with increasing calcination temperature. Such vacancy is essential to impart Lewis acid character and proposed to play a crucial role in carboxylic acid ketonization [54]. In the present study, oxygen vacancies were not related to the ketonization activity, but they were clearly pronounced for the selectivity to palmitone as shown in Table 2. Furthermore, to test the mechanism, the data of TiO2 calcined with different gases to adjust the oxygen vacancies was provided. The TiO2 samples were calcined by different gases (N2, H2, and Air) with a flow rate of 300 ml min−1 at 500 °C for 2 h (10 °C min−1). Fig. 7(a, c, e, and g) displays evidence of oxygen vacancies in TiO2 with different calcination gases as indicated by XPS. The TiO2 catalyst calcined with N2 gas exhibited the highest oxygen vacancies among all catalysts. The oxygen vacancies which were varied by different calcination gases increased in the following order: TiO2, Air (28.3%) < TiO2, no calcination (40.3%) < TiO2, H2 (41.4%) < TiO2, N2 (44.9%). Product distributions after the ketonization of methyl palmitate over TiO2 with different calcination gases and the data of oxygen vacancies are summarized in Table 3. In this proof, however, oxygen vacancies were not related to the ketonization activity, but they were significantly pronounced for the selectivity to palmitone as expected. Other products were identified as undesired products derived from the catalytic cracking. The catalytic cracking was found to undergo on BAS [32,56,57], especially on strong BAS [58]. From a summary of the data in Table 2, it was found that the number of strong BAS were not responsible for the catalytic cracking during the ketonization. The result showed that CeO2, which provided the lowest strong BAS, was investigated by the highest cracking. Next section, characterization of spent catalysts, provided fruitful data to clarify these points. 3.3 Characterization of spent catalysts The textural properties of the spent catalysts were investigated and compared to the fresh ones as shown in Table S1. It was clear that SBET, pore size, and Vpore decreased after the reaction. Many studies in the literature have reported that the structure of the catalyst was destroyed by carbon accumulation, leading to the decrement of SBET, pore size, and Vpore [59]. XRD patterns of spent TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2, which are compared to the fresh ones, are shown in Fig. 1 (blue line). Any phase changes were not observed over the catalysts after the ketonization of methyl palmitate. In other words, the TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 catalysts still presented anatase, cubic, beta, and monoclinic phases after the ketonization, respectively. The changes of surface acidity over the spent catalysts were investigated, which were compared to the fresh ones, by the in situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption at 40 °C as shown in Fig. 8. According to the literatures, the BAS generation over catalyst was improved by hydrogen spillover effect. Ebitani et al. [60] studied the BAS generation over Pt/SO4 2−–ZrO2 catalyst in the presence of hydrogen flow by monitoring the IR spectra of pyridine adsorption. They found that the BAS was produced, and the LAS were decreased instead. Hattori et al. [61] also proposed a mechanism that hydrogen molecules are firstly dissociated on platinum and Co–Mo catalysts to form the hydrogen atoms. Then, they subsequently spill onto the support and their migration to LAS occurred. Likewise, in our previous work, the LAS transformation was investigated on non-reducible and reducible oxides in the presence of hydrogen using in situ DRIFTS of adsorbed NH3. The introduction of hydrogen led to a decrement in the amount of ammonia chemisorbed on the LAS, and an increment in the amount of ammonium ions over the BAS with TOS. It was proposed that the migration of ammonia from the LAS to the BAS took place during the introduction of hydrogen [42,43]. For ketonization process, hydrogen was supplied via many mechanisms. For instance, the decomposition of dimethyl ether (by-product of methyl ester ketonization) [33,62,63], the formation of ketone major product through retro-Tishchenko mechanism, followed by aldol addition and deformylation of ester [64] and the consumption of the substrate into coke could provide an internal supply of hydrogen on the surface of the catalyst [37]. Table 4 summarizes the changes of surface acidity after the ketonization over TiO2, CeO2, and ZrO2. No apparent changes in the LAS and BAS were observed over TiO2 catalyst. On the other hand, the result shows that there were changes in the surface acidity during the ketonization over CeO2 and ZrO2. For the spent catalysts, the increment of the number of BAS was observed, whereas the number of LAS decreased instead, especially on the spent CeO2. The decrease in LAS and the generation of BAS were balanced, providing a confirmation for the transformation of LAS into the BAS in this study. The LAS transformations were found in the following order: TiO2 (no transformation) < ZrO2 (10.8%) < CeO2 (29.6%) while the BAS produced in the following order: TiO2 (no generation) < ZrO2 (8.1%) < CeO2 (27.5%). Hattori et al. [61] pointed out that hydrogen promoted the catalytic activity of cumene cracking over Pt/SO2 −4 – ZrO2 catalyst. Im et al. [65] revealed that surface hydroxyls, presumably BAS, were important for utilizing the catalytic functions of hydrogen spillover. These might be the reason why the catalytic cracking on CeO2 catalyst was the highest although its surface contained the lowest of the number of total Bronsted acid sites, especially for the lowest of strong BAS before the ketonization as observed on the fresh catalyst. To support the result of LAS transformation to the new BAS, the result of hydrogen uptake ascribed to the surface hydrogen spillover, was provided as shown in Fig. 5. Hydrogen spillover on non-reducible and reducible oxides was studied by many researchers [65–69]. Hydrogen spillover on non-reducible oxides is energetically improbable if there are no surface defect sites. In contrast, hydrogen spillover on reducible oxides takes place easily. However, the catalysts used in this work were classified as reducible oxides [70,71]. Among TiO2, CeO2, and ZrO2, the amounts of hydrogen spillover were in the order: TiO2 < CeO2 < ZrO2. TiO2, which was characterized by the lowest hydrogen spillover, provided the lowest transformation of LAS as expected. This was consistent with many reports as mentioned previously. However, not only surface hydrogen spillover, but also the strength of LAS is directly related to the LAS transformation to the new BAS. Weaker LAS over the catalyst enhanced the rate of LAS transformation [42,43]. From the in situ DRIFTS of adsorbed NH3 result as summarized in Table 2, CeO2 showed mostly weak LAS over its surface while medium LAS were apparently found over ZrO2 catalyst. This was why CeO2 catalyst exhibited the highest degree of the LAS transformation to the new BAS although the hydrogen spillover over its surface was lower than that of ZrO2 catalyst. Nevertheless, these LAS transformations would be interfered by oxygen vacancies. Many theoretical studies revealed that vacancy sites in semiconductors can easily capture hydrogen since the vacancies always possess high surface energy [72,73]. Mao et al. [74] reported that hydrogen spillover from iron to oxygen vacancies leads to the trapped form of oxygen vacancy-hydrogen (OV-H) over the TiO2−xHy catalyst. Therefore, the result of surface hydrogen spillover was discussed and a data of H2-TPD in case of TiO2 with different calcination gases was further provided to investigate how the oxygen vacancies affected the surface hydrogen spillover, which are shown in Fig. S2†. It was found that no signal was detected at low temperature region on all calcined catalysts, likewise, indicating no hydrogen adsorbed on the metal sites. Large peaks were assigned to hydrogen spillover species appeared at high temperature regions as expected. The amounts of hydrogen spillover are summarized in Table 5. It was clear that the catalyst, which was investigated by the highest oxygen vacancies, presented the lowest hydrogen spillover on its surface. In other word, higher surface hydrogen spillover was found on the catalyst with lower oxygen vacancies. Moreover, the oxygen vacancies of all catalysts were plotted against the amount of hydrogen spillover as shown in Fig. 11a. The plot displayed a directly proportional trend, which confirms that the oxygen vacancies could trap the surface hydrogen to inhibit its spillover. Subsequently, the transformation of LAS to the new BAS was diminished. Furthermore, as investigated by XPS, oxygen vacancies were observed on the spent TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 as shown in Fig. 3(b, d, f, and h), and on the spent TiO2 with different calcination gases as illustrated in Fig. 7(b, d, f, and h). It was found that the number of oxygen vacancies decreased after the ketonization and the percentage decreases of the oxygen vacancies were calculated and summarized in Table 5. The decreased percentage in oxygen vacancies over the spent catalysts was in the following order: CeO2 < ZrO2 < TiO2 < MnO2. Considering the case of TiO2 calcined with different gases, the decreased percentage of the oxygen vacancies over the spent catalysts increased in the following order: TiO2, Air < TiO2, H2 < TiO2, N2. Likewise, it was found that the Eg values obtained from the UV–Vis profiles shifted to higher values on all spent catalysts. This means the lower amount of oxygen vacancies was found over the spent catalysts compared to their fresh ones, which was consistent with the XPS result. These decreases in oxygen vacancies of the spent catalysts were also proven that the hydrogen occupied the oxygen vacancies as also seen by Cui et al. [75]. As the previous discussion, the BAS could induce cracking reaction of both hydrocarbon (methyl palmitate) and desired product (palmitone). When the new BAS was no longer produced as the active site for the cracking of hydrocarbon and palmitone products during the ketonization process, the selectivity to palmitone was significantly pronounced as revealed by a correlation between oxygen vacancies and palmitone selectivity (Fig. 11b). Another interesting data of such cracking results was considered to conduce towards a mechanism. According to the catalytic testing result (Table 1), the undesired products came from the cracking of hydrocarbon and palmitone. It was clear that the cracking of palmitone was dominant for overall cracking. Similarly, this trend was observed in the case of TiO2 catalysts which were adjusted the oxygen vacancies by different calcination as shown in Fig. 12. Palmitone cracking sharply declined more than hydrocarbon cracking when the higher oxygen vacancies were tuned. It indicates that, in this study, the enhancement of palmitone selectivity was the result of the reduction of palmitone cracking during the ketonization of methyl palmitate. Hence, the selectivity to palmitone markedly depended on the surface oxygen vacancies. In addition, TPO experiments were used to investigate the locations of the coke components over spent TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 catalysts, including TiO2 catalysts with different calcination, which are shown in Fig. 9. One peak appeared for each catalyst, which centered at 450, 280, 375, and 400 °C for TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2, respectively. Table 5 shows the characterization data summarized for the amount of coke deposition on the catalysts. The data clearly show that coke deposition increased in the following order: ZrO2 (0.20%) < CeO2 (0.23%) < TiO2 (1.11%) < MnO2 (2.95%). Likewise, the spent catalysts of TiO2 with different calcination gases, which were tested a mechanism, were also investigated the coke formation. Coke deposition on these TiO2 catalysts was in the following order: TiO2, Air (0.90%) < TiO2, H2 (1.15%) < TiO2, N2 (1.19%). Fig. 11c shows a good correlation between the oxygen vacancies over the catalysts and the coke deposition on their surfaces. The plot shows directly proportional trend, which indicates that the higher number of oxygen vacancies led to the coke deposition. In the previous work from our group, the coke storage materials that reduced the deactivation of dehydrogenation catalyst were studied over acidic TiO2, ZrO2, and Al2O3 nanomaterials. It was reported that oxygen vacancies over the added nanomaterials play a crucial role for capturing coke precursors, leading to a decrease in coke deposition on the dehydrogenation catalyst. The catalyst having the highest number of oxygen vacancies, provided the highest degree of adsorption of coke precursors and consequently the highest degree of coke deposition was found [76]. These results showed the same trend with the observed results in this study. However, the surface hydrogen spillover controlled via oxygen vacancies would clarify these phenomena. Generally, the advantage of hydrogen spillover for discharging coke deposition from the catalyst surface is the reaction with surface carbon, in which it can be removed as methane [77]. Zhao et al. [78] studied addition of Pt to Ni catalysts in steam reforming of ethylene glycol. They reported that the Ni in the reduced state by the electron transfer and the hydrogen spillover from Pt site to Ni catalyst efficiently inhibited the coke deposition over its surface. From the H2-TPD and XPS results, in this study, it was suggested that the oxygen vacancies could trap the surface hydrogen spillover as a result of the catalyst with higher oxygen vacancies that was investigated by the lower hydrogen spillover, resulting in the higher coke deposition. Additionally, the coke formation was consistent with the increasing of a peak assigned to a C–O band (OS) on the spent catalysts as confirmed by XPS, indicating carbon replacement over oxygen as observed in our previous work [76] and Solanki et al. [79]. Furthermore, a qualitative analysis of coke structures on the spent catalysts was conducted using FT-IR spectroscopy and the spectra are presented in Fig. 10. The IR bands at 2950–3020 cm−1 are assigned to CH vibrations of CH3 species in aliphatic nature of coke. The bands at 1400–1575 cm−1 are ascribed to the skeleton vibration of CC in aromatic nature of coke. Apparently, the FT-IR spectra indicate the coke deposited on the spent catalysts containing both aliphatic and aromatic cokes. Table 6 is a summary of the coke structures found on the spent catalysts. The peak corresponding to aromatic coke is much higher than that to aliphatic coke, especially on MnO2 catalyst, suggesting the relatively high aromatic character of the coke. The aromatic coke increased in the following order: ZrO2 < CeO2 < TiO2 < MnO2. On the other hand, the aliphatic coke increased in the following order: MnO2 < TiO2 < CeO2 < ZrO2, which was in contrast to that of aromatic coke. The percentage of the coke structures was calculated to investigate the propagation of coke. Wang et al. [80] and a recent study from our group [76] revealed that the formation of aliphatic coke was initially observed and the amount of aromatic coke subsequently increased with increasing temperature, leading to a decrease in amount of aliphatic coke observed by in situ DRIFT study. This result suggested that the aliphatic coke transformed into the aromatic coke and this transformation was related to the deep dehydrogenation. The deep dehydrogenation can remove H atoms from the adsorbed intermediate, which results in more C–metal interaction, and eventually leads to higher reaction barriers. Coke formation will occur if carbon centers are completely dehydrogenated, but not removed from the catalyst surface [81]. In the present study, it was found that the transformed coke as aromatic character was found in the following order: MnO2 (87.2%) > TiO2 (63.7%) > CeO2 (54.7%) > ZrO2 (35.5%). This suggested that the deep dehydrogenation obviously occurred over MnO2 catalyst. In contrast, the coke structures found on ZrO2 catalyst showed the high amount of aliphatic character, indicating less deep dehydrogenation to form aromatic coke. Yaoyuan et al. revealed that the active sites for efficient CH bond dissociation in alkanes over metal oxides can be metal cations located at an oxygen vacancy [82]. From the mechanism of hydrogen trapped in oxygen vacancies, the catalyst with the higher surface oxygen vacancies provided the lower hydrogen spillover, leading to the higher coke deposition as evidenced by XPS, H2-TPD, and TPO results. This phenomenon arose because hydrogen could not suppress the deep dehydrogenation reaction, resulting in the transformation of aliphatic coke to aromatic coke. In other words, the catalyst with the lower surface oxygen vacancies was characterized by the higher hydrogen spillover. Consequently, the deep dehydrogenation to form the aromatic coke was inhibited by the hydrogen spillover. These results were consistent with that the amount of coke deposition over the catalysts closely associated with the aromatic structure. This qualitative analysis of coke structures and their transformation was one of evidences confirming the mechanism of hydrogen trapped by the oxygen vacancies Figs. 11 and 12. In summary, a model representing the role of oxygen vacancies in palmitone selectivity and coke formation during the ketonization of methyl palmitate is shown in Scheme 1. The ketonization of methyl palmitate took place over the weak LAS, as expected. The transformation of LAS was promoted by hydrogen spillover to form the new BAS. Meanwhile, cracking reaction was effectively catalyzed by these new BAS. As a result, the selectivity to undesired products was more pronounced. As seen in the proposed mechanism, the oxygen vacancies could trap the hydrogen atom, and subsequently the transformation of LAS to BAS was suppressed. Thus, the new BAS as active sites for the catalytic cracking were no longer produced, especially the cracking of palmitone. This led to increased selectivity to palmitone. When hydrogen atom was trapped by the oxygen vacancies and it could not spill to suppress the deep dehydrogenation reaction, as the result, the coke deposition was dominant. The lack of hydrogen spillover caused the formation of aromatic coke, which came from the transformation of aliphatic coke. 4 Conclusion The present study showed that the selectivity to palmitone for the ketonization of methyl palmitate could be improved by utilizing acid oxide catalysts containing high oxygen vacancies. TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 were investigated in this work. From the catalytic testing result and NH3-IR experiments, the weak LAS were the active sites for the ketonization of methyl palmitate as expected. XPS result revealed that oxygen vacancies were not related to the ketonization activity, but they were pronounced for the selectivity to palmitone. A data of TiO2 calcined with different gases to adjust the oxygen vacancies was provided for testing the mechanism. In this proof, however, oxygen vacancies still played the important role in the selectivity to palmitone. It was concluded that the selectivity to palmitone, therefore, markedly depended on the surface oxygen vacancies. The useful experiments used to characterize the catalysts were conducted to clarify how the oxygen vacancies worked in this study. For instance, the H2-TPD experiments were used to observe the hydrogen spillover on surface of the catalysts. The XPS technique and NH3-IR experiments were conducted to investigate the changes in oxygen vacancies and acidity after the ketonization, respectively. As proven by H2-TPD, XPS, and NH3-IR experiments, a mechanism was proposed that the oxygen vacancies could trap the hydrogen atom to inhibit its spillover, and subsequently the LAS transformation to new BAS was suppressed. Thus, the new BAS as active sites for the catalytic cracking were no longer produced, especially the cracking of palmitone. This led to the decrement of selectivity to undesired products. In other words, higher selectivity of palmitone can be achieved. However, the hydrogen spillover, generally, can suppress the coke deposition over the catalysts. This study showed that when the hydrogen atom was trapped in the oxygen vacancies, the coke deposition was dominant. This phenomenon arose because hydrogen could not suppress the deep dehydrogenation reaction, resulting in the transformation of aliphatic coke to aromatic coke revealed by FT-IR spectroscopy experiment. Moreover, the amount of coke deposition found over the catalysts closely associated with the aromatics structure. Eventually, the role of oxygen vacancies trapping the hydrogen spillover was determined, which had the positive effect on the selectivity to palmitone but the negative effect on the coke formation over the catalysts. Hopefully, these observed results should be a useful data for the design of high surface oxygen vacancies over solid acid catalysts for the ketonization of long-chain methyl esters, in which the ketone product selectivity and the coke deposition over the catalyst can be controlled. coredata.dc:description: In the present study, TiO2, CeO2, MnO2, and ZrO2 catalysts were used to investigate the catalytic performance in methyl palmitate ketonization. The reaction was accelerated by weak Lewis acid, while the oxygen vacancies promoted the palmitone selectivity. The use of various characterization techniques revealed that oxygen vacancies played an important role for trapping the hydrogen atom and inhibited its spillover. This caused the suppression of the Lewis acid transformation to new Bronsted acid. Thus, the cracking of palmitone over the new Bronsted acid was diminished, leading to the decrement of selectivity to undesired products. However, when the hydrogen atom was trapped in the oxygen vacancies, the coke deposition was dominant. This phenomenon arose because hydrogen could not suppress the deep dehydrogenation, resulting in the transformation of aliphatic coke to aromatic coke. The role of oxygen vacancies was determined, and it had the positive effect on the palmitone selectivity, whereas it raised the coke formation.
coredata.dc:title: Determining the role of oxygen vacancies in palmitone selectivity and coke formation over acid metal oxide catalysts for the ketonization of methyl palmitate
